vote.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to show which person or party you want, or whether you support a plan, by marking a piece of paper, raising your hand etc
vote.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: In 1918 British women got the right to vote.
I’ve voted Democrat all my life.
I voted for the Labour candidate in the last election.
53% of Danes voted in favour of the Maastricht treaty.
The people of Ulster had finally been given a chance to vote on the issue.
Congress voted to increase foreign aid by 10%.
Shareholders voted to reject the offer.
vote.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to choose someone or something for a particular prize by voting for them
vote.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: In 1981 Henry Fonda was voted Best Actor for ‘On Golden Pond’.
vote.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: if a parliament, committee etc votes a sum of money for something, they decide by voting to provide money for that particular purpose
vote.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Parliament has voted £20 million extra funding for road improvements.
vote.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: How many people voted Yes in the referendum?
Cubans in the city of Miami have traditionally voted Republican.
The committee voted unanimously in favour of the proposition.
On Dec. 7 delegates voted overwhelmingly to strike.
The Senate voted narrowly to continue funding the controversial project.
People appear to have voted tactically in order to prevent the Conservative candidate from gaining a seat.
All those aged 18 or over are eligible to vote.
We must encourage people to register to vote.
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0]: You vote for someone or something
Who are you going to vote for at the next election?
Most MPs voted for the bill
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[1]: You vote against someone or something
The committee voted against the decision
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[2]: Congress voted to change the law
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[3]: Parliament, Congress etc passes a bill or law
Parliament passed a law against drug smuggling
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[4]: Pass is often used in the passive in this meaning
The law was passed by a big majority
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[5]: Elect is often used in the passive
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[6]: She was elected as MP for Corby
vote.translation[0].note_box[1].items[8]: You elect someone to Parliament, Congress etc
She was elected to the Senate
vote.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: vote
to show which person or party you want, or whether you support a plan, by marking a piece of paper, raising your hand etc
I’ve voted Democrat all my life.
You can vote for your favourite singer.
A majority of the people voted for independence.
In tomorrow’s election, many young people will be voting for the first time.
elect
to choose a leader, representative, or government by voting, so that they become the new leader, representative etc
He was elected mayor of London.
the newly-elected government
I think we should start by electing a new chairman.
go to the polls
if a country or voters go to the polls, they vote in an election – used especially in news reports
The US goes to the polls in November.
The economic crisis could well be a decisive factor when voters go to the polls this autumn.
take a vote
if a group of people at a meeting take a vote, they vote about something
We should take a vote on whether or not to accept their offer.
They took a vote and picked Bernard.
cast your vote
to mark a piece of paper, call a telephone number etc in order to vote
The first votes have been cast in the country’s general election.
Click here to cast your vote.
ballot
to ask the members of an organization to vote on something in order to decide what to do
The union will ballot its members on whether to go ahead with the strike action.
veto
to vote against something that other people have agreed on, so that it cannot happen
The president has the right to veto any piece of legislation.
vote.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: an act of voting in an election or meeting, or the choice that you make when you vote
vote.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: A vote for us is not a wasted vote.
The proposal was rejected by 19 votes to 7.
policies designed to win votes in the South
It’s the club secretary that counts the votes.
Harkin won 74 percent of the votes cast.
The House of Representatives approved the budget, with 52 votes in favor, 16 against and 12 abstentions.
vote.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: an occasion when a group of people vote in order to decide something or choose a representative
vote.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The results of the vote were surprising – 80% of workers favoured strike action.
Unless anyone has anything to add, we’ll take a vote.
Let’s have a vote on it.
Let’s put it to the vote. All those in favor raise your hands.
There will be a citywide vote  (=all the voters in a particular city) on the matter.
vote.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The motion was passed by a vote of 215 to 84.
vote.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to show by marking a paper, raising your hand etc which person you want to elect or whether you support a particular plan
vote.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: 23% of shareholders voted for him as a new director.
The board voted against filing a suit to recover the money.
Committee members voted 9-2 to raise interest rates.
The settlement offer collapsed after the House of Representatives voted it down  (=rejected it).
The chairman was voted in  (=elected) by a 12-1 majority.
vote.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: when a group of people vote in order to decide or choose something
vote.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The results of the vote were surprising — 80% of workers favoured strike action.
Creditors will take a vote on the reorganization plan later this year.
vote.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: a choice or decision that someone makes by voting in an election or meeting
vote.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: The union was only 23 votes short of the majority it needed.
vote.translation[3].definitions[3].defin: the total number of votes made in an election or the total number of people who vote
vote.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: Their proposal to oust the board got 78% of the vote.
